item.title: View Cluster List
item.description:
This section explains how to view the list of clusters.

Prerequisites

You should have the Cluster Viewing permission on the KubeSphere platform. For more information, refer to "Platform Roles".

Steps

  1. Log in to the KubeSphere web console with a user who has the Cluster Viewing permission.

  2. Click Cluster Management.

  • The cluster list provides the following information:

    Parameter Description

    Name, Identifier, and Description

item.title: Edit Cluster Information
item.description:
This section explains how to edit cluster information.

You can edit the identifier, provider, and description of the cluster. KubeSphere does not support editing the name of an already added cluster.

Prerequisites

You should have the Cluster Management permission on the KubeSphere platform. For more information, refer to "Platform Roles".

Steps

  1. Log in to the KubeSphere web console with a user who has the Cluster Management permission.

  2. Click Cluster Management.

  3. Click on the right of the cluster you want to edit, then choose Edit Information from the dropdown list.

  4. In the Edit Information dialog, set the identifier, provider and description for the cluster, then click OK.

    Parameter Description

    Identifier

item.title: Add Cluster Tags
item.description:
This section explains how to add cluster tags.

You can use tags to categorize and manage clusters.

Prerequisites

  • You should have the Cluster Management permission on the KubeSphere platform. For more information, refer to "Platform Roles".

  • You need to create cluster tags in advance. For more information, please refer to Create Cluster Tags.

Add Tags to a Single Cluster

  1. Log in to the KubeSphere web console with a user who has the Cluster Management permission.

  2. Click Cluster Management.

  3. Click the icon on the right side of the cluster you want to add tags, then select Add Tags from the dropdown list.

  4. In the Add Tags dialog, choose the key and value for the tag, click Add, and then click OK.

    After adding the tags, you can search for clusters by tags by clicking on the search box above the cluster list.

item.title: Edit Cluster Configuration
item.description:
This section introduces how to edit the cluster configuration of a member cluster, i.e., adjust the ks-agent configuration parameters.

In addition to configuring the cluster when adding a member cluster, you can also edit the cluster configuration after the member cluster has been added.

Prerequisites

You should have Cluster Management permissions on the KubeSphere platform.

Steps

  1. Log in to the KubeSphere web console with a user who has the Cluster Management permission.

  2. Click Cluster Management.

  3. Click on the right side of the cluster you want to edit, and then select Edit Configuration from the dropdown list.

  4. Enter the ks-agent information in the Edit Configuration dialog box, and then click OK.

item.title: Update kubeconfig
item.description:
This section explains how to update the kubeconfig information of member clusters.

After adding member clusters on the KubeSphere platform, if there are changes in the access information of the member clusters, you need to update the kubeconfig of the member clusters.

Note

KubeSphere only supports updating the kubeconfig information of clusters added through direct connections and does not support updating the kubeconfig information of clusters added through agent connections.

item.title: Remove Member Clusters
item.description:
This section explains how to remove member clusters.

Note

  • The host cluster cannot be removed.

  • After removing a member cluster, KubeSphere will no longer manage that cluster. Existing Kubernetes resources in the cluster will not be deleted.
Warning

After a cluster is removed, the existing multi-cluster configuration data in the cluster will not be automatically cleared. Uninstalling KubeSphere or deleting associated resources may result in data loss. Be sure to follow the Clean up Multi-Cluster Configuration Data steps on the removed cluster.

item.title: Re-host a Member Cluster to Another Host Cluster
item.description:
This section introduces how to re-host a removed member cluster to another host cluster.

Unbinding a Cluster in Normal State

If a member cluster is removed while in a normal state, no additional operations are required. The member cluster can be directly re-hosted by another host cluster. For detailed steps, please refer to Add a Member Cluster.

Unbinding a Cluster in Abnormal State

If a member cluster is removed while in an abnormal state, run the following command on the member cluster to clear the hosting information. After that, the cluster can be normally re-hosted by another host cluster.
